Rule.Name: Bearish Belt Hold
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) A significant gap up occurs but prices are heading downwards only. After a significant gap up causes large profit-taking. Expect lower prices.

Rule.Name: Bearish Dark Cloud Cover
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The first day is a long white day, and the second day is a black day which opens above the first day's high and closes within the first day but below the midpoint. Although a gap-up indicates a uptrend, prices are heading downwards and probabilities are high that prices continue to fall.

Rule.Name: Bearish Doji Star
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The first day is a long white day. The second day is a doji star that gaps above the first day. A star indicates a reversal and a doji indicates indecision. This pattern usually indicates a reversal following an indecisive period. You should wait for a confirmation before trading a doji star.

Rule.Name: Bearish Engulfing Lines
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern) A small white line (first day) is engulfed by a large black line (second day). This pattern is strongly bearish if it occurs after a significant up-trend (i.e., it acts as a reversal pattern).

Rule.Name: Bearish Evening Star
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern) The first day is a long white day, the second day gaps above the first day's close and the third day is a long black day. The "star" indicates a possible reversal and the black line confirms this. The star can be empty or filled-in. This is a bearish pattern signifying a potential top.

Rule.Name: Bearish Hanging Man
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) A small real body (i.e., a small range between the open and closing prices) and a long lower shadow (i.e., the low was significantly lower than the open, high, and close). This pattern is bearish if it occurs after a significant uptrend, but detection requires only a minor uptrend measured by a 5-period SMA.

Rule.Name: Bearish Harami
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) A line with a small black body (second day) falls within the area of a larger white body (first day). This pattern indicates a decrease in momentum.

Rule.Name: Bearish Harami Cross
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) First day is a long white day and the second day is a Doji day that is engulfed by the first day's body. It is similar to a Harami, except the second line is a Doji (signifying indecision). This pattern indicates a decrease in momentum.

Rule.Name: Bearish Kicking
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) A white marubozu followed by a black marubozu where the black marubozu gaps below the 1st day's open. The gap is a resistance area, and a downtrend is expected.

Rule.Name: Bearish Long Black Line
Rule.Description: (1-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) Prices open near the high and close significantly lower near the period's low. This is a bearish line.

Rule.Name: Bearish Separating Lines
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern) The 1st day is a long white day followed by a black day that opens at the opening price of the 1st day. Although the 1st day prices are heading upwards, the second day shows significant downturn with an insignificant upper shadow. The downtrend should continue.

Rule.Name: Bearish Shooting Star
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) Price gap up to the upside with a small real body. The star's body must appear near the low price and the line should have a long upper shadow. This pattern suggests a minor reversal when it appears after a uptrend.

Rule.Name: Bearish Side-By-Side White Lines
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern) A black day followed by a gap down of two almost identical white days. No trend-reversal occurs on the 2nd and 3rd day, thus the downtrend is still intact.

Rule.Name: Bearish Three Black Crows
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) Three black days with lower closes each day where each day opens lower but within the body of the previous day. Strong down-trend indicates a continuation of falling prices.

Rule.Name: Bearish Three Inside Down
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The first two days are a Bearish Harami pattern followed by a black day that closes below the second day. The 3rd day is the confirmation of the Bearish Harami pattern.

Rule.Name: Bearish Three Outside Down
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern) The first two days are a Bearish Engulfing pattern followed by a black day that closes below the second day. The third day is the confirmation of the Bearish Engulfing pattern.

Rule.Name: Bearish Tri Star
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) Three Dojis where the second Doji gaps above the 1st and the third. High indecision during three days suggests that the trend is about to change. This pattern appears very seldom on securities with high volume.

Rule.Name: Bullish Belt Hold
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern) A significant gap down occurs but prices are heading upwards only. After a significant down gap causes a short-covering and strong buying. Expect higher prices.

Rule.Name: Bullish Doji Star
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) First day is a long black day, the second day is a Doji day that gaps below the first day. A "star" indicates a reversal and a Doji indicates indecision. This pattern usually indicates a reversal following an indecisive period. You should wait for a confirmation before trading a Doji star.

Rule.Name: Bullish Engulfing Lines
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) A small black line (first day) is engulfed by a large white line (second day). This pattern is strongly bullish if it occurs after a significant downtrend (i.e., it acts as a reversal pattern).

Rule.Name: Bullish Hammer
Rule.Description: (1-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) A small real body (i.e., a small range between the open and closing prices) and a long lower shadow (i.e., the low was significantly lower than the open, high, and close). Detection requires at least a minor downtrend measure by a 5-period SMA.

Rule.Name: Bullish Harami
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) A line with a small white body (second day) falls within the area of a larger black body (first day). This pattern indicates a decrease in momentum.

Rule.Name: Bullish Harami Cross
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) First day is a long black day and the second day is a Doji day that is engulfed by the first day's body. It is similar to a Harami, except the second line is a Doji (signifying indecision). This pattern indicates a decrease in momentum.

Rule.Name: Bullish Inverted Hammer
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) Price gap down to the downside with a small real body. The star's body must appear near the low price and the line should have a long upper shadow. This pattern suggests a minor reversal when it appears after a downtrend.

Rule.Name: Bullish Kicking
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) A black marubozu followed by a white marubozu where the white marubozu gaps up the 1st day's open. The gap is a support area, and an uptrend is expected.

Rule.Name: Bullish Long White Line
Rule.Description: (1-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The prices open near the low and close significantly higher near the period's high. This is a bullish line.

Rule.Name: Bullish Morning Star
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The first day is a long black day, the second day gaps below the first day's close and the third day is a long white day. The "star" indicates a possible reversal and the white line confirms this. This is a bullish pattern signifying a potential bottom.

Rule.Name: Bullish Piercing Line
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The first day is a long black day, the second day is a white day which opens below the first day's low and closes within the first day but above the midpoint. This is a bullish pattern and the opposite of a Dark Cloud Cover.

Rule.Name: Bullish Separating Lines
Rule.Description: (2-bar pattern) The 1st day is a long black day followed by a white day that opens at the opening price of the 1st day. Although the 1st day prices are heading downwards, the second day shows significant upturn with an insignificant lower shadow. The uptrend should continue.

Rule.Name: Bullish Side-By-Side White Lines
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern) A white day followed by a gap up of two almost identical white days. No trend-reversal occurs on the 2nd and 3rd day, thus the uptrend is still intact.

Rule.Name: Bullish Three Inside Up
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The first two days are a Bullish Harami pattern followed by a white day that closes above the second day. This is usually the confirmation of the Bullish Harami pattern.

Rule.Name: Bullish Three Outside Up
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The first two days are a Bullish Engulfing pattern followed by a white day that closes above the second day. The third day is the confirmation of the Bullish Engulfing pattern.

Rule.Name: Bullish Three White Soldiers
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern) Three white days with higher closes each day and where each day opens above but within the body of the previous day. This pattern represents strong uptrend.

Rule.Name: Bullish Tri Star
Rule.Description: (3-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) Three Dojis where the second Doji gaps below the 1st and the third. High indecision during three days suggests that the trend is about to change. This pattern appears very seldom on securities with high volume.

Rule.Name: Neutral Doji
Rule.Description: (1-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The price opens and closes at the same price. This pattern implies indecision. Double doji lines (two adjacent doji lines) imply that a forceful move will follow a breakout from the current indecision.

Rule.Name: Neutral Marubozu
Rule.Description: (1-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) A candlestick that has no upper and lower shadows.

Rule.Name: Neutral Spinning Top
Rule.Description: (1-bar pattern) The distance between the high and low, and the distance between the open and close, are relatively small.

Rule.Name: Reversal Dragonfly Doji
Rule.Description: (1-bar pattern) The open and close are the same, and the low is significantly lower than the open, high, and closing prices. This pattern signifies a turning point.

Rule.Name: Reversal Gravestone Doji
Rule.Description: (1-bar pattern) The open, close, and low are the same, and the high is significantly higher than the open, low, and closing prices. This pattern signifies a turning point.

Rule.Name: Reversal Long-legged Doji
Rule.Description: (1-bar pattern, stable at bar 25) The open and close are the same, and the range between the high and low is relatively large. This pattern often signifies a turning point.
